docs.text:
Docs Home
¶


Welcome
¶


This site contains documentation that is hopefully relevant to you.


Navigation
¶


You can use the tabs at the top of the site to select a category. The left sidebar will then show all of the documentation in that category. The right sidebar lets you go to specific sections or important places within each article.

docs.title: Navigation

docs.text:
Use TeamViewer for remote assistance
¶


Applies to: TeamViewer 11, 12, 13
¶


TeamViewer is a free program used to provide remote support for computer problems over the Internet. As such, it can be a more convenient alternative to arranging an in-person visit for many computer issues.


This guide describes how to download and run TeamViewer in order to initiate a remote support session.


Arranging a remote support session
¶


Before you can download TeamViewer and join a remote support session, the first thing you will need to do is arrange a time for your session to take place. The best way to do this is often to talk to a technician you trust.




Warning




For your security, we will not initiate a remote support session without explicit permission.
 If someone you do not trust contacts you offering remote support, you should decline. You should also decline if you are not requesting support. Allowing unsolicited remote support sessions risks the safety of your computer, of information, and of your identity.


Using QuickSupport on Windows
¶


Download and run QuickSupport
¶


Prior to beginning your remote support session, you need to download and run TeamViewer


To download TeamViewer QuickSupport, 
click here
. You can also copy and paste this link into your web browser: 
http://go.nerdoncloud.com/teamviewer
.




Info




The next two steps are for Google Chrome only. Different web browsers may ask you to either Save or Run the file. If asked, you should 
Save
 the file, and then move it to your 
Desktop
.


After the download finishes, locate it in the bar at the bottom of the window. Click the 
arrow
 to the right of the file name, and select 
Show in folder
.




Move the file out of this folder by dragging and dropping it onto your 
Desktop
. Close the folder window If desired.


right-click
 the downloaded file. Click 
Run as administrator
.




Click 
Run
 to accept the security warning.




If a User Account Control window appears, click 
Yes
, and provide an administrator password if needed.


Establishing a TeamViewer Session


The TeamViewer window will now appear. Note the 
green light
 towards the bottom of the window, as well as the status, "Ready to connect (secure connection)." This indicates that TeamViewer is now able to accept an incoming remote support offer.


Make a note of 
your ID
 and the four-digit temporary 
password
 (obscured), which the support staff will need in order to securely connect to your computer.




Once the support technician has this information, they can take temporary control of your computer. You will be able to see every action they perform. This typically includes seeing the mouse cursor moving, and seeing programs opening and closing. While the technician has control over the mouse and keyboard, you can still override their actions by using the mouse or the keyboard yourself. This is useful when replicating an issue for support staff to resolve, and when you need to enter a password.


If you want to stop a support session in-progress, close TeamViewer. Your technician can also end the session at any time.


Once the remote support session is over, TeamViewer will automatically return control of your computer to you.


Always close TeamViewer once your remote support session is finished. This ensures that no one can access your computer remotely unless TeamViewer is opened again.




Sponsored sessions


When the support session ends, you may see messages promoting the paid edition of TeamViewer. These often appear as a 
sponsored session
 message. TeamViewer shows these messages at random because we can provide remote support at no cost to you.


If you see any promotional messages, you can 
close
 these windows and continue using your computer, with no further action required.




For more information, or to arrange a remote support session, please email our dedicated support staff at 
support@nerdoncloud.com
.


Using QuickSupport for Mac (OS X)
¶


Downloading and Running TeamViewer


Prior to beginning your remote support session, the TeamViewer program will first need to be downloaded and run from your computer. While TeamViewer QuickSupport is available for Windows, Mac, and Linux computers, for your convenience, the link below will automatically detect which version is best for your device.


To download TeamViewer, 
click here
. Alternatively, copy and paste the following link into your browser's address bar: 
http://go.nerdoncloud.com/teamviewer
.


Depending upon the operating system and browser you use, you may be prompted to either run the file or save it. In this example we are using OS X 10.11 El Capitan and Google Chrome. For other operating systems, the options may look slightly different; however, the basic procedure is the same on almost every Mac.


After the download finishes, locate it in the bar at the bottom of the window Click the 
arrow
 to the right of TeamViewerQS.dmg, and select 
Show in Finder
.




In the Finder window that appears double-click 
TeamViewerQS.dmg
 to open it.




Next, double-click the 
QuickSupport icon
 to open it when prompted.




If prompted, click 
Open
 to accept the security warning. Provide an administrator password if necessary.




Establishing a TeamViewer Session


The TeamViewer window will now appear. Note the 
green light
 towards the bottom of the window, as well as the status, "Ready to connect (secure connection)." This indicates that TeamViewer is now able to accept an incoming remote support offer.




Make a note of 
your ID
 and the four-digit temporary 
password
 (obscured), which the support staff will need in order to securely connect to your computer.


Once the support technician has this information, they can take control of your computer. You will be able to see every action they perform, so do not be alarmed to see the mouse cursor moving and windows opening and closing. While the technician has control over the mouse and keyboard, you can still override their actions by moving your own mouse or using the keyboard yourself. This is useful in certain situations, such as entering passwords, or when replicating an issue for support staff to resolve.


If at any point you wish to stop an ongoing support session, simply close the TeamViewer window to disconnect the technician from your computer.


Once the remote support session is over, TeamViewer will automatically return control of your computer to you.


Always close the TeamViewer application once the remote support session is finished. This ensures that no one can access your computer remotely unless TeamViewer is opened again.


Please note: Some customers may see a dialog advertising the paid edition of TeamViewer or a 
sponsored session
 dialog. This is an unfortunate limitation of the version of TeamViewer used by our support team to offer assistance at no cost to you; however, you may simply 
close
 these windows to continue using your computer, with no further action required.


For more information, or to arrange a remote support session, please email our dedicated support staff at 
support@nerdoncloud.com
.
docs.title: Use TeamViewer for remote assistance

docs.text: TeamViewer is a free program used to provide remote support for computer problems over the Internet. As such, it can be a more convenient alternative to arranging an in-person visit for many computer issues.  This guide describes how to download and run TeamViewer in order to initiate a remote support session.
docs.title: Applies to: TeamViewer 11, 12, 13

docs.text: Before you can download TeamViewer and join a remote support session, the first thing you will need to do is arrange a time for your session to take place. The best way to do this is often to talk to a technician you trust.   Warning   For your security, we will not initiate a remote support session without explicit permission.  If someone you do not trust contacts you offering remote support, you should decline. You should also decline if you are not requesting support. Allowing unsolicited remote support sessions risks the safety of your computer, of information, and of your identity.
docs.title: Arranging a remote support session

docs.text: Prior to beginning your remote support session, you need to download and run TeamViewer  To download TeamViewer QuickSupport,  click here . You can also copy and paste this link into your web browser:  http://go.nerdoncloud.com/teamviewer .   Info   The next two steps are for Google Chrome only. Different web browsers may ask you to either Save or Run the file. If asked, you should  Save  the file, and then move it to your  Desktop .  After the download finishes, locate it in the bar at the bottom of the window. Click the  arrow  to the right of the file name, and select  Show in folder .   Move the file out of this folder by dragging and dropping it onto your  Desktop . Close the folder window If desired.  right-click  the downloaded file. Click  Run as administrator .   Click  Run  to accept the security warning.   If a User Account Control window appears, click  Yes , and provide an administrator password if needed.  Establishing a TeamViewer Session  The TeamViewer window will now appear. Note the  green light  towards the bottom of the window, as well as the status, "Ready to connect (secure connection)." This indicates that TeamViewer is now able to accept an incoming remote support offer.  Make a note of  your ID  and the four-digit temporary  password  (obscured), which the support staff will need in order to securely connect to your computer.   Once the support technician has this information, they can take temporary control of your computer. You will be able to see every action they perform. This typically includes seeing the mouse cursor moving, and seeing programs opening and closing. While the technician has control over the mouse and keyboard, you can still override their actions by using the mouse or the keyboard yourself. This is useful when replicating an issue for support staff to resolve, and when you need to enter a password.  If you want to stop a support session in-progress, close TeamViewer. Your technician can also end the session at any time.  Once the remote support session is over, TeamViewer will automatically return control of your computer to you.  Always close TeamViewer once your remote support session is finished. This ensures that no one can access your computer remotely unless TeamViewer is opened again.   Sponsored sessions  When the support session ends, you may see messages promoting the paid edition of TeamViewer. These often appear as a  sponsored session  message. TeamViewer shows these messages at random because we can provide remote support at no cost to you.  If you see any promotional messages, you can  close  these windows and continue using your computer, with no further action required.   For more information, or to arrange a remote support session, please email our dedicated support staff at  support@nerdoncloud.com .
docs.title: Download and run QuickSupport

docs.text: Downloading and Running TeamViewer  Prior to beginning your remote support session, the TeamViewer program will first need to be downloaded and run from your computer. While TeamViewer QuickSupport is available for Windows, Mac, and Linux computers, for your convenience, the link below will automatically detect which version is best for your device.  To download TeamViewer,  click here . Alternatively, copy and paste the following link into your browser's address bar:  http://go.nerdoncloud.com/teamviewer .  Depending upon the operating system and browser you use, you may be prompted to either run the file or save it. In this example we are using OS X 10.11 El Capitan and Google Chrome. For other operating systems, the options may look slightly different; however, the basic procedure is the same on almost every Mac.  After the download finishes, locate it in the bar at the bottom of the window Click the  arrow  to the right of TeamViewerQS.dmg, and select  Show in Finder .   In the Finder window that appears double-click  TeamViewerQS.dmg  to open it.   Next, double-click the  QuickSupport icon  to open it when prompted.   If prompted, click  Open  to accept the security warning. Provide an administrator password if necessary.   Establishing a TeamViewer Session  The TeamViewer window will now appear. Note the  green light  towards the bottom of the window, as well as the status, "Ready to connect (secure connection)." This indicates that TeamViewer is now able to accept an incoming remote support offer.   Make a note of  your ID  and the four-digit temporary  password  (obscured), which the support staff will need in order to securely connect to your computer.  Once the support technician has this information, they can take control of your computer. You will be able to see every action they perform, so do not be alarmed to see the mouse cursor moving and windows opening and closing. While the technician has control over the mouse and keyboard, you can still override their actions by moving your own mouse or using the keyboard yourself. This is useful in certain situations, such as entering passwords, or when replicating an issue for support staff to resolve.  If at any point you wish to stop an ongoing support session, simply close the TeamViewer window to disconnect the technician from your computer.  Once the remote support session is over, TeamViewer will automatically return control of your computer to you.  Always close the TeamViewer application once the remote support session is finished. This ensures that no one can access your computer remotely unless TeamViewer is opened again.  Please note: Some customers may see a dialog advertising the paid edition of TeamViewer or a  sponsored session  dialog. This is an unfortunate limitation of the version of TeamViewer used by our support team to offer assistance at no cost to you; however, you may simply  close  these windows to continue using your computer, with no further action required.  For more information, or to arrange a remote support session, please email our dedicated support staff at  support@nerdoncloud.com .
